title.narrative: Yes I Do Indonesia

description.narrative: Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM), teenage pregnancies and female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C). With this project, by changing the attitude of cummunity members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevent legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM, teenage pregnancies and FGM/C. The project will be implemented between 2016 and 2020 by Plan Nederland, together with partners AMREF, Rutgers, CHOICE, KIT and the Netherlands' Embassies in the relevant countries. It will be carried out in Ethiopia, Kenya, Zambia, Malawi, Indonesia and Pakistan.

title.narrative: Goal 5. Policy makers and duty bearers commit to implement laws and policies on CM and FGM and C

description.narrative: Plan and Choice contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: # of new or adjusted national and local law (incl. by-laws) and policies prohibiting CM and FGM and C (disaggregated by CM and FGM and C and by policies laws national level local level)

description.narrative: The data was collected through Key informant interviews with NGO staff and policy makers.

comment.narrative: In the Marriage Law No. 1 of 1974, the minimum age requirement for women to marry is 16 years old and men 19 years. Many child marriages are Hindu and muslim marriages

In Sukabumi: one local regulation child protection No. 1/2018, Perdes No. 7/2016, a village head decree No. 3/2018 (total 3); In West Lombok: a circular letter of the regent on Anti-Child Marriage Movement (Gerakan Anti Merarik Kodeq – GAMAK) Nomor. 843.4/34/BKBPP/2016, awig-awig desa in the village (total 2); In Rembang: a local regulation on child protection No. 28/2016, a KPAD regulation in the village level (total 2). Total in the three locations (7)

title.narrative: Political awareness increased and political will created

description.narrative: Plan and Choice contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in policy makers actively and openly supporting gender equality and girls rights

description.narrative: The data was collected through Key informant interviews with NGO staff and policy makers.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Policy makers seldom actively support gender equity and rights.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all There is a new local regulation (perda) issued in Sukabumi concerning gender mainstreaming. There are programs addressing gender equality (gender mainstreaming in three districts) district gender working group in district government (West Lombok) affirmative action for girls' participation in village meetings - programs vulnerable girls (prevent them from child trafficking. sex workers). However policy makers continue to be biased against girls in cases of premarital pregnancy (supporting pregnant unmarried girls to be married off) and stigma surround pregnant unmarried girls.

title.narrative: Political awareness increased and political will created

description.narrative: Plan and Choice contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in policy makers actively and openly supporting gender equality and girls rights

description.narrative: The data was collected through Key informant interviews with NGO staff and policy makers.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Policy makers seldom actively support gender equity and rights.
There are many programs that continue to support gender equality and girls rights, however policy makers still hold a gender biased view.

title.narrative: Men and boys are successfully and actively engaged to reduce CM- TP and FGM and C

description.narrative: Plan and Choice contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: qualitative Changes observed relative to baseline in active engagement of men and boys in strategies reducing FGM and C and CM and TP

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all The active engagement of men and boys in reducing TP CM and FGM and C is low
Active engagement of fathers and boys (15-24) in strategies reducing CM and TP is increasing, the engagement in the prevention of FGM/C is low

title.narrative: Men and boys are successfully and actively engaged to reduce CM- TP and FGM and C

description.narrative: Plan and Choice contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: qualitative Changes observed relative to baseline in active engagement of men and boys in strategies reducing FGM and C and CM and TP

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all The active engagement of men and boys in reducing TP CM and FGM and C is low

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all There are some male champions in most of intervention villages such as religious and community/traditionals leaders fathers and KPAD members. In district level the regional secretary in Sukabumi gave raising awareness about gender equality and gender mainstreaming to the local bureaucrats. In West Lombok men are are members of the district working group to monitor and evaluate gender mainstreaming program. However in all district fathers' knowledge and engagement in SRHR issues and FGM/C remains limited. Few boys have begun to participate in youth posyandu as cadres and leaders.

title.narrative: Goal 5. Policy makers and duty bearers commit to implement laws and policies on CM and FGM and C

description.narrative: Plan and Choice contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: # of new or adjusted national and local law (incl. by-laws) and policies prohibiting CM and FGM and C (disaggregated by CM and FGM and C and by policies laws national level local level)

description.narrative: The data was collected through Key informant interviews with NGO staff and policy makers.

comment.narrative: More policies at the national (one law) and local (local regulation - perda perbup - regent regulation - circulation letter from the office of women empowerment and child protection concering Child-Friendly City and Child-Friendly City) in the district and village levels on child marriage and child protection (policies on the establishment of KPAD and PATBM in every village). Total numbers of local policies in three districts: 9 in district level and 13 in village level. The enforcement of the regulations of the prevention of child marriage or child protection in the villages is identified by the way the village officials refuse to issue a recommendation letter to the office of religious affairs the case of child marriage. so that child marriage cannot be formally registered. There is still no policies on FGM/C and TP.

title.narrative: Adolescent girls can decide if when and whom to marry and if when and with whom to have children and are protected from female genital mutilation.

description.narrative: Plan and Choice

title.narrative: % of girls below 18 years who left school due to pregnancy

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Sukabumi- Lombok Barat). The survey included question about child marriage- teenage pregnancy and female circumcision. We obtained a sample size of 1528 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. a total of 1534 questionnaires were administered- slightly above to the planned target.

title.narrative: Adolescent girls can decide if when and whom to marry and if when and with whom to have children and are protected from female genital mutilation.

description.narrative: Plan and Choice

title.narrative: % of girls below 18 years who left school due to marriage

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Sukabumi- Lombok Barat). The survey included question about child marriage- teenage pregnancy and female circumcision. We obtained a sample size of 1528 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. a total of 1534 questionnaires were administered- slightly above to the planned target.

title.narrative: Adolescent girls can decide if when and whom to marry and if when and with whom to have children and are protected from female genital mutilation.

title.narrative: Community and gate keepers understand benefits of changing norms and are aware of alternatives in relation to CM and TP and FGM

description.narrative: Plan contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of CM and TP

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the knowledge about harms of CM and TP

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Negative consequences of CM and TP are not known
Many gatekeepers, especially women, seem to be more knowledgeable about the harms of CM and TP.

title.narrative: Community and gate keepers understand benefits of changing norms and are aware of alternatives in relation to CM and TP and FGM

description.narrative: Plan contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of CM and TP

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the knowledge about harms of CM and TP

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Negative consequences of CM and TP are not known

title.narrative: Community and gate keepers understand benefits of changing norms and are aware of alternatives in relation to CM and TP and FGM

description.narrative: Plan contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of FGM and C

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the knowledge about harms of FGM and C.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all The risk and harms were not known by any of the young respondents

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Some gatekeepers are more knowledgeable about the practice of FGM/C and support the prevention of FGM/C. Village midwives raise awareness about the harms of FGM/C to parents who asked them to perform circumcision. The beliefs that FGM/C is to curb female's sexual desire and to purify female bodies are prevailing. Religious and community leaders also see FGM/C as strongly recommended in the Islamic teaching.

title.narrative: Community and gate keepers understand benefits of changing norms and are aware of alternatives in relation to CM and TP and FGM

description.narrative: Plan contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of FGM and C

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the knowledge about harms of FGM and C.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all The risk and harms were not known by any of the young respondents
Some gatekeepers begin to aware of the harms of FGM/C. The health workers are more knowledgeable than parents, religious leaders, and young people.

title.narrative: Goal 1. Community members and gate-keepers have changed attitudes and take action to prevent CM FGM and C and TP.

description.narrative: Plan contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent CM and TP (more or less supportive compared to baseline)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the attitudes and actions re. CM and TP.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Religious leaders and parents have an influential role in the promotion of CM and TP. There are positive exceptions. Parents with little knowledge are propmiting the practices.

Most parents and religious leaders have a positive attitude towards prevention of TP and CM, however only a few religious and traditional leaders are involved in actively preventing CM and TP. Trained teachers have positive attitudes, but only a few teachers talk about the prevention of CM & TP in schools

description.narrative: Plan contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent CM and TP (more or less supportive compared to baseline)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the attitudes and actions re. CM and TP.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Religious leaders and parents have an influential role in the promotion of CM and TP. There are positive exceptions. Parents with little knowledge are propmiting the practices.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Most gatekeepers in the villages sub-district and districts are supportive in particular in the prevention of CM. However in the cases of premarital pregnancy gatekeepers such as parents religious and community leaders continue to believe that marrying off the pregnant girls are the best solution. All districts have worked with religious leaders to prevent CM due to premarital pregnancy. A few KPAD started to prevent this for example KPAD in Kediri West Lombok while some KPAD advocated for the continuation of the girls education in Sukabumi.

title.narrative: Goal 1. Community members and gate-keepers have changed attitudes and take action to prevent CM FGM and C and TP.

description.narrative: Plan contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent FGM and C (more or less supportive compared to baseline)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the attitudes and actions re. FGM.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Some Muslim parents mentioend not to circumcise anymore- there is a change.

Many gatekeepers perceive FGM/C as a mandatory practice in Islam. Most parents now go to midwives to only symbolically perform the FGM/C. The traditional birth attendants are not allowed to perform the FGM/C.

title.narrative: Goal 1. Community members and gate-keepers have changed attitudes and take action to prevent CM FGM and C and TP.

description.narrative: Plan contributed to the outcome

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent FGM and C (more or less supportive compared to baseline)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the attitudes and actions re. FGM.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Some Muslim parents mentioend not to circumcise anymore- there is a change.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Some gatekeepers (in particular midwives and health cadres KPAD FAD) have shown that they are not favor of the practice of FGM/C and support the prevention of FGM/C. Paraji continue to perform FGM/C. Most parents religious and community paraji continue to believe that FGM/C is part of religious practice and tradition. Mothers (sometimes grandmothers) usually decide the practice of FGM/C fathers also support the practice.

title.narrative: Adolescent girls and boys have increased access to ASRHR information and services- and child protection services

description.narrative: This indicator is based on the latest Demographic and Health Survey (DHS). No contributing partner

title.narrative: % of current use of contraceptive among all women 20-24 years - any modern method

description.narrative: Data from DHS 2012.

title.narrative: Adolescent girls and boys have increased access to ASRHR information and services- and child protection services

description.narrative: This indicator is based on the latest Demographic and Health Survey (DHS). No contributing partner

title.narrative: % of current use of contraceptive among all women 15-19 years - any % modern method

description.narrative: Data from DHS 2012.

title.narrative: Adolescent girls and boys have increased access to ASRHR information and services and child protection services

description.narrative: no contributing partner

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in current access to SRHR information by girls and boys aged 15 to 24 years

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years. And focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and groups of boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Most girls and boys aged 15 to 24 years report to have limited access to various SRHR information sources.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all More sources of information are available for youth. Most SRHR information is not comprehensive textbook based information (leaves little room to contextualize within local SRHR issues or emphasizing the biological aspects of reproductive health). Only schools that implement Setara have more comprehensive information. Teachers in Sukabumi whose schools implement Setara utilize social media to deliver Setara topics such as through instagram live or whatsapp chat. In the community health centers there is still no special room and special time alloted for youth to have SRHR consultation.

title.narrative: Adolescent girls and boys have increased access to ASRHR information and services and child protection services

description.narrative: no contributing partner

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in current access to SRHR information by girls and boys aged 15 to 24 years

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years. And focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and groups of boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Most girls and boys aged 15 to 24 years report to have limited access to various SRHR information sources.
The majority of girls and boys aged 15 to 24 years report to have an increased access to various SRHR information sources.

title.narrative: Adolescent girls and boys have increased access to ASRHR information and services- and child protection services

description.narrative: no contributing partner

title.narrative: % of young mothers aged 15-24 years indicating using MALEcondoms

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Sukabumi- Lombok Barat). The survey included question about child marriage- teenage pregnancy and female circumcision. We obtained a sample size of 1528 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. a total of 1534 questionnaires were administered- slightly above to the planned target. No contributing partners.

title.narrative: % girls aged 15-24 who ever received education about sexuality and sexual health
Goal 3. Adolescent girls and boys take informed action on their sexual health

description.narrative: no contributing partner

title.narrative: % Girls between 15 and 24 that have ever utilized SRHR services- including modern contraceptives

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Sukabumi- Lombok Barat). The survey included question about child marriage- teenage pregnancy and female circumcision. We obtained a sample size of 1528 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. a total of 1534 questionnaires were administered- slightly above to the planned target. No contributing partners.

title.narrative: Goal 3. Adolescent girls and boys take informed action on their sexual health

description.narrative: no contributing partner
